welcome.data: Warm-Up Prompt: “What makes a good scene in a game? Think about your favorite game—what's the first thing you saw or interacted with?” Students will share quick thoughts in pairs and then discuss as a class.

aim.data: Objective: Students will create and run a basic scene using Godot 4, including a root node and a simple visual node (e.g., sprite or label), and test their scene in the editor.

review.data: Review from Lesson 1.2: Opening the Godot Editor, creating a project and exploring the FileSystem, node and scene basics (node hierarchy, root node, saving scenes). Quick recall quiz: What is a node? What does every scene require?

relevant.data: Mini-lecture and live demo in Godot: Show how to create a new scene, add a root node and child nodes, set properties like position and text, save the scene, and run it using the Play button.

interactive.data: Students will create a new scene with a root node and at least one child node. They will customize basic properties, save the scene, and run it in the Godot editor.

ownership.data: Independent Challenge: Students will design their own Welcome Scene with at least two child nodes and one customized property (e.g., text or color). They will test and refine their scenes independently.

resonate.data: Exit Ticket: “What was the most challenging part of creating your own scene today? What did you enjoy most?” Students write a brief reflection or submit it digitally.

supplies.data: Computers with Godot 4 installed, projector for live demo, optional sample assets (sprite or font), and a reflection submission method (paper or LMS).
